title: 112_s3553
content: The "Benefits to Research and American Innovation through Nationality Statutes Act of 2012" or the "BRAINS Act" allows immigrant visas for certain advanced STEM graduates. The "BRAINS Act" enables immigrant visas for advanced STEM graduates with a master's degree or higher from a US research institution. Up to 55,000 visas are available for qualified immigrants in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields. The "BRAINS Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM graduates with a US master's degree or higher. Requirements include taking classes in the US, having a job offer related to the degree, approved labor certification, and receiving a wage level equal to others with similar qualifications. The "BRAINS Act" allows immigrant visas for STEM graduates with a US master's degree or higher, with specific requirements for job offers and wage levels. Definitions for fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics and US research institutions of higher education are provided. The "BRAINS Act" defines a United States research institution of higher education as an institution excelling in STEM fields, existing for at least 10 years, and not providing any. The "BRAINS Act" outlines criteria for a US research institution of higher education, including accreditation by the Secretary of Education and prohibiting incentive payments for enrollment or financial aid success. The "BRAINS Act" makes amendments to visa limitations and procedures for granting immigrant status, including changes to unused visas, limitations to foreign states, and labor certification for certain immigrants. The "BRAINS Act" amends labor certification and qualification for certain immigrants, including those holding a doctorate degree in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics from a US research institution. The "BRAINS Act" amends labor certification requirements for certain immigrants, including submitting a job order to the State workforce agency for the labor the alien seeks to perform. The "BRAINS Act" requires job orders to be posted on the official agency website for at least 30 days and includes links to State workforce agencies. Additionally, subparagraph (D) is amended to include section (6) in addition to (2) and (3). The "BRAINS Act" requires job orders to be posted on the official agency website for at least 30 days and includes links to State workforce agencies. Section 212(p) of the Act is amended to require employers to demonstrate that compensation for foreign workers must match or exceed that of other employees with similar experience. Additionally, a study on the National Science Foundation's use of classification authority is due by June 30, 2017. The "BRAINS Act" mandates job orders to be posted on the official agency website for 30 days and requires equal compensation for foreign workers. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide public information on aliens granted status under section 203(b)(6) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The amendments made by this section require employers to provide details on the occupations and job titles of aliens sought, with an effective date of October 1, 2012. The amendments will be repealed after a 2-year period from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. STUDENT VISA REFORM. Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding student visas, specifying residency requirements for foreign students pursuing full-time studies, with exceptions for STEM fields. Conforming amendments are also made to the Act. Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows foreign students in STEM fields to pursue full-time studies at higher education institutions. Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows visa revalidation for certain nonimmigrant visa holders, and age-out protections for children are also included. Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act includes rules for determining the age of a child in immigrant petitions and for children of U.S. citizen fiancees. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act clarifies that the age of an alien for an adjustment of status application should be based on their age at the time the petition is filed with the Secretary of Homeland Security. SEC. 6. RETENTION OF PRIORITY DATES. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the retention of priority dates for aliens aged 21 or older when a parent files a petition for them. Additionally, permanent priority dates are established under certain conditions. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act establishes priority dates for petitions filed with the Secretary of Homeland Security or State. Priority dates are retained for subsequent petitions if the original petition was approvable. The effective date of the amendments is specified. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to any alien beneficiary of a classification petition pending on or after such date. Increased number of immigrant visas for spouses of high-skilled workers with permanent residence, based on the number of aliens removed from the US in the previous fiscal year.
